title.narrative: Cabo Delgado ACM Joint Response

description.narrative: Conflict and displacement have resulted in rapidly increased Shelter, WASH and food needs as confirmed by Caritas’ rapid gap analysis. With shelter already covered by C-M, we will address the urgent food and WASH needs with the main objective to save the lives of 29,055 IDPs and host communities. Food: To address people’s immediate food needs, 811 HH will receive food kits comprised of rice (25kg), maize meal (25kg), beans (7kg), salt (1kg) and vegetable oil (2L). The kit is distributed on a monthly basis for 3 months. For the longer-term food needs, and to improve dietary diversion and nutrition, each HH receives seeds & tools for small scale vegetable farming (vegetable seeds, catana, hoe, watering can), incl. training. Vegetable seeds can be planted year-round. WASH: To reduce public health risks, 1001 HH will receive hygiene and dignity kits and WASH NFIs. Hygiene promotion will be done using door-to door campaign. Shared latrines are not culturally accepted and therefore 387 individual latrines will be constructed by the HH, using material provided by C-M and compliant with SPHERE. The location of the latrine is selected in consultation with women and PSN to ensure their safe access. Those HH unable to provide labour for the construction will be supported by the community through Cash for Work. C-M will conduct construction training and supervision. Clean water supply will be ensured for 400 HH through drilling of 2 boreholes for the IDPs and rehabilitation of 2 water points for the host communities, in line with SPHERE standards. Additionally, we will complementary provide WASH services in the CFSs of SOS. To improve quality programming, distribution points will be safe (crowd control) and near beneficiaries’ plots, and times will be convenient to reduce protection risks. FSL and WASH cluster standards and guidelines will be followed. C-19 awareness and prevention will be integrated, including safety and protection measures for beneficiaries and staff.
IDPs in resettlement camps and the most vulnerable host families close to the reselttment camps

Since Oct. 2017, insurgents have carried out increasingly frequent and intense attacks in Cabo Delgado, Mozambique. In 2020 the violence escalated and the number of IDPs increased from 110.000 in March 2020 to almost 700.000 by April 2021. The insurgents use extreme violence and many people are severely traumatized, arriving after a dangerous journey. They had to leave everything behind and many have lost family members. According to the HRP, 1.3 mln people (IDPs and Host) need HA. IDPs lack safe and dignifying shelter and are arriving in communities with inadequate WASH, putting pressure on limited WASH services already available. The lack of WASH is a public health risk affecting PLW and children under 5 disproportionately and is a protection concern for women and girls, increasing the risk on GBV. Food insecurity increased as families fled their homes and crops, leaving 950,000 people food insecure (HRP 2021). Around 270,000 IDPs have settled in Pemba and surrounding districts like Mecufi. In Mecufi, 4,000 IDPs (and increasing) plus host communities are in urgent need of shelter, food and WASH, as Caritas assessment shows. Although the govt creates sites where an IDP HH is given a plot of land, these open fields are without any infrastructure. People don’t have seeds and tools to grow their vegetables and as they already exhausted their coping mechanisms, they need food now.

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Availability of, access to and consumption of food
FSC-I2: Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs (non-cash)

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

title.narrative: Short-term livelihood support
FSC-I1: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihoods assets

description.narrative: Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, restricted cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: Water Supply
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

title.narrative: Accountability
ACC-I1: Number of crisis-affected people who are also involved in the design, implementation, monitoring and/or evaluation of the programme

description.narrative: Participation is defined as the involvement of crisis-affected people in one or more phases of the programme: assessment, design, implementation, monitoring or evaluation. Participation does not take place when activities are carried out in exchange for a salary of 'in-kind' payment unless the affected people are involved in decision-making processes and have an impact on decisions that affect them. Please describe in the actvity description what this involvement specifically entails and in which phase of the program conflict-affected people are involved.

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion (Awareness)
WSH-I6: Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: Hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities. Could be training, campaigns, radio broadcasts, flyers etc. Excludes the distribution of Hygiene/dignity kits that should be covered under WHS-I1.

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion
WSH-I1: Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: Regular and timely access: 250g soap/p/m for personal hygiene, 200g soap/p/month for laundry. This includes hygiene/dignity kits. Access may be in-kind or though voucher distribution or through unconditional restricted cash to enable beneficiary to buy soap (without compromising access to other basic needs). Distributed items need to be culturally acceptable i.e. take into account local practice and expectations.

title.narrative: Excreta disposal
WSH-I2: Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

description.narrative: Access: ratio (user/facility) of 1 toilet for a max. 20 people, distance < 50 metres from dwellings, or as locally agreed. Clean: regular cleaning and maintenance for public facilities. Dignified: Use of toilets respect cultural preference and is arranged by household(s) and/or segregated by sex. Unsafe facilities: unstable (unlined) pits with risk of collapse, pits accessible to vectors, pits contaminating water tables and poorly sited facilities which expose women and girls to attacks, especially at night. Functional facility: fully constructed, in working order and properly maintained, of a type and in a location acceptable to intended users, with hand washing facilities and anal cleansing material.

title.narrative: Adaptations to JR
ACC-I2: Number of adaptations in the design and/or implementation of the JR, as a result of the input from beneficiaries.

description.narrative: Active participation of beneficiaries could lead to concrete proposals in programme design and/or on how to improve existing implementation. In the activity description/comment field, indicate how this input from beneficiaries is gathered (planned) and at mid/end-term stage, what input was received from beneficiaries and to which adaptations this has led.

title.narrative: Humanitarian Aid Corporate Indicators
The humanitarian response was Appropriate

description.narrative: Appropriateness is assessed according to the SPHERE standards. A response is considered to be appropriate based on needs assessment, taking account of rights, needs, culture, age, gender, disabilities and context, and equity (non-discrimination and equal access.

title.narrative: Number of beneficiaries reached (HA)

description.narrative: Number of people who benefitted directly or indirectly from humanitarian assistance and/or resilient recovery services and/or disaster preparedness from activities in a humanitarian response implemented by Cordaid and implementing partners.

title.narrative: Humanitarian Aid Thematic Indicators
Number of local organisations strengthened in Emergency preparedness and Response

description.narrative: Number of local organisations strengthened in Emergency preparedness and Response by Cordaid and/or implementing partners whereby a strengthened organisation refers to one that is better prepared and able to respond to a crisis based on assessments made in the PRA.

title.narrative: The Humanitarian Response was Timely

description.narrative:
SPHERE: Communities and people affected by crisis, including the most vulnerable groups, consider that the timing of the assistance and protection they receive is adequate. DRA: timely depends on the nature of the acute crisis (slow versus sudden onset). If it is an acute sudden onset crisis a response is considered timely if we decide to respond within 48 hours and if we initiate the response within 72 hours. If it is a slow onset crisis, it is timely if we initiate the response in 3 weeks after we decide that the crisis meets the criteria of an acute crisis.
The applicable definition depends on the type of crisis (protracted versus acute). The SPHERE definition should be used in more protracted crisis where there is (more) time to conduct assessments and measure satisfaction of the response in the eyes of people affected. The DRA definition should be used for acute crises, where it is more important to initiate the response as soon as possible and look at our own processes.

title.narrative: Climate Resilience
The project integrates climate risks in programming

description.narrative: The integration of climate risks in programming includes an undertaking of concrete actions to reduce and/or mitigate risks related to climate change impact and disaster risks ( for example droughts, erosion, salinization, flooding, etc.) The projects we refer to could be on the themes of health education, justice, security, disaster management, finance and livelihoods.
